comments_since_last_sample.body:
As a reminder, this subreddit [is for civil discussion.](/r/politics/wiki/index#wiki_be_civil)

In general, be courteous to others. Debate/discuss/argue the merits of ideas, don't attack people. Personal insults, shill or troll accusations, hate speech, any suggestion or support of harm, violence, or death, and other rule violations can result in a permanent ban. 

If you see comments in violation of our rules, please report them.

 For those who have questions regarding any media outlets being posted on this subreddit, please click [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/politics/wiki/approveddomainslist) to review our details as to our approved domains list and outlet criteria.

***


*I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/politics) if you have any questions or concerns.*
We were so busy fighting to rid ourselves of trump and didn’t even notice these two.
Well Sinema said she was too smart to be President.

There used to be standards for political candidates. No scandals, sexual, financial or anything in between.  They used to have to be educated, reasonably intelligent.  They used to be champions of community service, pillars of the community, not the dregs of humanity. They couldn't be the receivers of buckets of donor money putting all that tit-for-tat crap in play. We're getting to the point of having to administer some sort of standardized testing to ensure the candidates don't harbor some bat-shit crazy theories. I certainly recommend they all have psych exams in order to be qualified to run for office.

“Remember our deal Krysten, we’ve paid you good money to hold this up”

“But what will my excuse be”

“Just act confused and don’t give any real reasons”

“Thank you, I really love money”

I mean I get Manchin and Sinema haven't done what Dems want them to do on these bills, but a lot of stuff Biden wants to do could actually be done by executive action. *cough* student loan forgiveness *cough*

Also maybe if they added another round of direct payments that may put more pressure by constituents to pass the damn thing. 

But if Dems lose the midterms, it won't (just) be because of this bill. It'll be because of a stagnant economy, hyperinflation, the Afghanistan pull out disaster and not delivering on even the campaign promises that don't require Congress.
I still can’t believe Sienema is teaching a class on the grift at ASU.

So many situations and actions over the past years have made it clear that there are huge systemic flaws in our process we need  to fix - national popular vote, campaign finance reform, the filibuster, lack of accountability in any real way from the Executive Branch, and so on.

These two are just the most recent poster children for donation driven representative opposed to the needs and desires of their constituents.
What's the solution? Remove voting and just implement whatever policy the media approves of?
